detailed_findings.content_snippet: Bitsight Threat Intelligence Briefing: Key Malware Trends Shaping Cyber Risk in 2025 The cybercrimeunderground continues to evolveinto a mature, service-based economy that mirrors legitimate technology markets. Threat actors are increasingly adopting professionalized business models, offeringmalware, access, and data-theft capabilities “as a service” to a broad audience of buyers. During the first half of 2025, Bitsight observed sustained growth in Malware-as-a-Service (MaaS) and Remote Access Trojan (RAT) activity across dark web forums and marketplaces. Ransomware operators remain active, and the ecosystem surroundingstealer and loader malwarecontinues to diversify. Emerging toolkits written in Rust, Go, and other cross-platform languages demonstrate the technical evolution of criminal development practices. Across sectors, healthcare, technology, and finance remain among the most frequently targeted industries.Healthcare continues to rank as the most impacted sector, with 93% of U.S

detailed_findings.content_snippet: F-Alert US Cyber Threats Bulletin December 2025 Discover the latest online threats and cyber security trends impacting US businesses and consumers, brought to you by F-Secure’s threat intelligence specialists. December’s F-Alert closes out the year with a roundup of 2025’s cyber threat landscape. It also highlights the credibility crisis of online reviews, the promises and perils of agentic browsers, and the latest forced-labor scam center dismantled by authorities. Throughout, we provide expert commentary and practical guidance to help navigate these risks. 2025 US Cyber Threat Recap: Key Lessons for the Year Ahead In 2025, US consumers lost an estimated $64.8 billion to scams, with 70% of American adults hit at least once. This year’s F-Alerts indicate that scams and AI-driven threats were the most prevalent, followed by malware and rising momentum for stronger consumer Online Reviews in Crisis: Can 5-Stars Be Trusted? Online review platforms are facing a crisis of credibility as AI-

detailed_findings.content_snippet: Understanding the Landscape of Remote Access Trojans and Malware in 2025 In the evolving world of cybersecurity, Remote Access Trojans (RATs) and Trojans remain central players in the underground ecosystem. These malicious tools are frequently discussed within dark web forums, showcasing their significant role as initial infection mechanisms. As depicted inFigure 1, there is a consistent level of RAT activity across dark web platforms. This figure reflects a comprehensive examination of mentions, marketplace listings, and infection telemetry, illustrating the persistent interest and usage of these tools. Comparatively, the general malware landscape exhibits stable activity but witnesses sporadic spikes typically aligned with the release of new stealer kits or ransomware variants.Figure 2provides insight into this broader malware activity, highlighting the somewhat predictable patterns that emerge amidst the ongoing threat. Emerging Malware Trends in 2025 As we forge ahead into 2025, we

detailed_findings.title: Top Cybersecurity Threats in 2025: Key Trends & Stats
detailed_findings.summary:
### 1. Intelligence Extraction

The global cybersecurity landscape for 2025 is characterized by an unprecedented scale of attacks and profound economic implications, with cybercrime projected to cost the world an astounding $10.5 trillion annually, effectively positioning it as the third-largest global economy. This translates to a continuous onslaught, with an incident reported to the FBI's IC3 roughly every 39 seconds in 2024, contributing to a 75% surge in known breaches compared to the previous year. The average cost of a data breach globally stands at $4.44 million, a slight decline from 2024, largely attributed to faster response times enabled by AI. However, this global average belies significant regional disparities, most notably in the United States, where breach costs soared to a record $10.22 million due to rigorous legal penalties and customer losses. Ransomware continues to be a dominant threat, implicated in 44% of breaches, though only 23% of victims now pay ransoms, a notable shift from prior years, yet recovery and downtime still cost an average of $5.08 million. Phishing remains the primary initial attack vector, accounting for 16% of breaches, closely followed by a dramatic doubling of third-party/supply chain compromises to 15%, highlighting significant vulnerabilities in human factors and vendor ecosystems. The healthcare sector consistently faces the highest breach costs at $7.42 million per incident, while the Middle East, despite facing nation-state caliber adversaries, saw an 18% decline in breach costs due to aggressive cybersecurity investments. Crucially, artificial intelligence is emerging as a double-edged sword: while attackers increasingly leverage AI (e.g., for deepfakes and advanced phishing), organizations extensively using AI and automation in their security defenses have demonstrably cut their breach lifecycle by 80 days and saved $1.9 million per incident, underscoring its critical role in mitigating financial fallout.

### 2. Strategic Implications

This intelligence paints a picture of cybersecurity evolving from a technical concern to a major macroeconomic and national security imperative. The staggering $10.5 trillion projected cost of cybercrime demands that organizations universally elevate cybersecurity to a core strategic priority, necessitating board-level oversight and significant, continuous investment. The persistent dominance of phishing and the dramatic surge in supply chain compromises highlight critical vulnerabilities in human factors and extended digital ecosystems, demanding enhanced employee training, rigorous third-party risk management frameworks, and robust vendor security assessments. The high costs associated with ransomware, even without payment, underscore the non-negotiable need for comprehensive incident response plans, resilient backup and recovery strategies, and proactive threat hunting capabilities. The success demonstrated by organizations leveraging AI and automation in defense, leading to reduced breach costs and faster containment, signals a clear opportunity for strategic investment in advanced security technologies to gain a decisive advantage against increasingly sophisticated, AI-augmented attacks. Regionally, the US market presents unique financial risks due to its stringent regulatory and litigious environment, requiring tailored legal and compliance strategies. The Middle East's ability to reduce breach costs through aggressive investment offers a compelling case study for other regions facing high-value targets, while Europe's stable costs under GDPR demonstrate the dual benefit of regulation in driving both compliance and preparedness. For industries like healthcare and manufacturing, the consistently high or surging threat levels necessitate sector-specific, hyper-focused security strategies and resource allocation. Overall, the data implies a future where cybersecurity resilience is directly correlated with economic viability and competitive advantage, necessitating a proactive, adaptive, and technology-forward approach to defense.

### 3. Key Entities

**Organizations:**
*   FBI (Internet Crime Complaint Center - IC3)
*   IBM (Cost of a Data Breach report)
*   Verizon (DBIR reports)
*   Google
*   Workday
*   Qantas
*   Salesloft
*   Drift

**Locations:**
*   Global
*   United States
*   Middle East
*   Europe (UK, Germany)
*   Asia Pacific (Japan, Australia, Singapore)
*   Africa

**Regulations/Standards:**
*   GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation)
*   HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act)
*   CCPA (California Consumer Privacy Act)

**People:**
*   None explicitly mentioned.
detailed_findings.content_snippet: Top Cybersecurity Threats in 2025: Data, Trends, and Key Insights A data-driven deep dive into the most critical cybersecurity threats shaping 2025 and what they mean for organizations. Surging Cybercrime Costs:Cybercrime is projected to cost the world $10.5 trillion annually by 2025, equivalent to the third largest economy globally. This translates to about $333,000 lost every minute to cyber attacks and fraud. Data Breach Expenses:Theglobal average cost of a data breach in 2025 is $4.44 million, a slight decrease of 9% year over year from the record $4.88 million in 2024. In the United States, breach costs hit a record $10.22 million more than double the global average due to higher legal penalties and customer loss. Ransomware Prevalence:Ransomware was involved in 44% of breaches in 2025, up from ~32% the year prior. However, only about 23% of victims paid a ransom, down from ~50% a few years ago as more organizations refused extortion demands. Even without paying, a ransomware inci

detailed_findings.content_snippet: The number of the year: Kaspersky detected half a million malicious files daily in 2025 Kaspersky’s detection systems discovered an average of 500,000 malicious files per day in 2025, marking a 7% increase compared to the previous year. Certain types of threats saw growth globally – there was a 59% surge in password stealer detections, a 51% growth in spyware detections and a 6% growth in backdoor detections compared to 2024. 500,000malicious files per day were discovered on average by Kaspersky's detection systems in 2025 These findings are part of the Kaspersky Security Bulletin series where we review the key cybersecurity trends of the past year. Windows remains the primary target for cyberattacks. 48% of users on Windows were targeted by different types of threats throughout 2025. For Mac users, this figure stands at 29%. Globally, 27% of users were attacked with web threats – these refer to malware that targets users when they are online. Web threats are not limited to online acti

detailed_findings.content_snippet: Kaspersky,the renowned Russian cybersecurity firm that has been banned for use in federal agencies across the United States, has recently released a comprehensive study warning of a global surge in cyber threats. The firm’s findings are particularly concerning as they reveal that its anti-malware software has been blocking over 500,000 malicious files each day so far in 2025. Additionally, Kaspersky’s threat analysts have pointed out that cyberattacks have impacted more than 27% of online users globally, with a significant proportion of them falling victim to malware and ransomware. The2025 Kaspersky Security Bulletin, which highlights key trends and insights into the cybersecurity landscape, emphasizes that Microsoft Windows continues to be the primary target for cybercriminals. According to the study, more than 48% of Windows users have been affected by various cyber threats, making the operating system the number one target for malicious activity. In contrast, Mac users faced a lowe

detailed_findings.content_snippet: MALWARE ATTACKS SEE 131% SPIKE IN 2025, LEADING CYBERSECURITY REPORT FINDS Malware email attacks surge 131% year-over-year, accompanied by a rise in scams (+35%) and phishing (+21%) 77% of CISOs identified AI-generated phishing as a serious and emerging threat 68% of organizations invested in AI-powered protection in 2025 PITTSBURGH,Nov. 19, 2025/PRNewswire/ -- In a year defined by acceleration,Hornetsecurity's annual Cybersecurity Reportrevealed that threat actors embraced automation, artificial intelligence, and social engineering at unprecedented speed, while defenders raced to adapt governance, resilience, and awareness programs to match. Analysis of over 6 billion emails processed monthly (72 billion annually) confirmed that email was a consistent delivery vector for cyber-attacks in 2025. Malware-laden emails surged by 131% year-over-year, accompanied by a rise in both email scams (+34.7%) and phishing (+21%). Threat actors were enabled to create even more convincing fraudulent c
